web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article40878580|title=KILLED IN FIRE|date=24 January 1940|publisher=|pages=3|via=Trove}} |- |1936 |28-10 |Mr. J. Sewell |O |P |1 |1 | |45 | | | |Crows Nest | |} == Coronial comments and advice == The coronial recommendations and comments varied considerably. Where the coroner's findings were made public, the decedent's name has been provided. The following comments and findings have been given Case 1: Aidan Bott 2006 (''i)      That there be education and advice provided by relevant agencies to school principals both public and private, as to the requirements for tree maintenance ...'' ''(ii)     That there be compulsory inspection of all trees in school yards in all schools, both public and private, ... at least every 6 months.'' ''(iii)    That such inspections be conducted by qualified arborists.'' Case 2: ''Based on the observations of the site inspection and with particular reference to the external appearance of the stem, as it probably would have appeared prior to the failure, it is unlikely that the subject tree would have been identified as a potential hazard if a routine tree inspection was undertaken'' Case 3: At ''the position of failure external examination revealed no visible signs of lack of integrity, however internal examination revealed fungal activity and significant decay. '' Case 4 (i) A regular (and documented) review of the area by an appropriate expert (an arborist);  (ii) A tree planting program that recognises and minimises the longer term risk;  (iii) Where a building or B.B.Q area is likely to be constructed an appropriate mechanism should be established for identifying potentially dangerous trees in the immediate area and reducing the risk. Case 5: ''The [arborist] concluded that it was'...hard to determine what actually occurred.  [For example,] the lean of the tree, the crown weight, exudations, the overall health and condition of the tree was undeterminable because the tree was inspected in a failed state ...  It is my opinion that from a visual inspection it would have been impossible to determine any major or minor internal structural decay, with normal weather conditions it would be considered unlikely for tree failure to occur but not impossible'' Case 6: ''... the accident was clearly caused by a structural fault with a dead tree that would certainly have been picked up with an arborist inspection of the tree prior to the accident'.'' ''It is apparent that whilst such inspection of trees is desirable to avoid a recurrence of such an accident, the reality is that it is just far too cost prohibitive for any rural Council to embark upon.”'' Case 6 [''The tree] was 21 metres in length and was dead with no living tissue noted.  [The arboricultural consultant] saw obvious signs of advanced decay as well as obvious signs of past and current termite activities. In [the consultant's] view the tree had been dead for approximately 3-5 years ...'' ''... at the time when camping grounds are being created for use by paying campers, an inspection by an arboricultural consultant, or similar professional, be conducted so as to ensure that hazards posed by trees will be kept to a minimum.'' ''... at camping grounds visited by regular campers, regular inspections should be conducted by persons with relevant training and experience to ensure that hazards are kept to a minimum and trees which are likely to fall on campsites are removed within a reasonable timeframe. I further recommend that any pruning be conducted by suitably experienced and qualified persons in accordance with Australian Standard 4373 (1996) Pruning of Amenity Tree Standards. I further recommend that a pruning cycle of 5 – 8 years be established in order to address developing structural issues''. Case 7 ''An arborist inspected the tree at the request of Police who reported that the tree was dead and most likely had been dead for about 12 months. The presence of a vine over the tree would have concealed its dead state from an untrained eye.'' Case 8: Rebecca Anne Penfold Jolly ''It is impractical to expect that every single tree in metropolitan Adelaide will be individually inspected and assessed. It is probably impractical to expect even that, within existing resources, every tree that might pose a risk if it failed will be so inspected.  Of course, when a risk has been drawn to a local authorities' attention, then it is incumbent upon that authority to carry out a complete inspection of that risk in accordance with generally accepted standards.'' Case 9: Bridget Wright ''[An] Arborist, inspected the tree the next day. He concluded:'' ·        ''The branch fell because the tree was unhealthy and had significant problems'' ·        ''There was extensive fungal decay at the site of the branch failure, affecting approximately two thirds of the diameter of its base'' ·        ''An aerial inspection also revealed a 3 metre cavity at the base of the main leaders that contained a large bee hive and there was also bracket fungi on a number of the other branches'' ·        ''While these defects would not have been obvious from the ground, there were enough indicators visible from the ground to warrant an aerial inspection'' ''As a result of these actions, over 9,000 trees have been removed from public school grounds across the State.'' ''There was nothing to indicate any specific concerns about the large Red Forest Gum tree in the playground on that day.'' ''What is clear from the evidence is that it was known that the large branch which failed was extended with significant end weight'' ==References== {{Reflist|6}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Accidental tree failures in Australia}} [[Category:Australia history-related lists]] [[Category:Death-related lists]] [[Category:Lists by death toll]] [[Category:Deaths in Australia]] [[Category:Accidental deaths in Australia]] [[Category:Lists of events in Australia]]

[[Image:Max More, Stanford 2006 (square crop).jpg|right|thumb|'''Max More''' at the 2006 Stanford [[Singularity Summit]].]] '''Max More''' (born '''Max T. O'Connor''', January 1964) is a [[philosophy|philosopher]] and [[futurists|futurist]] who writes, speaks, and consults on advanced decision-making about [[emerging technologies]].<ref>Alex Heard, "Technology Makes us Optimistic; They Want To Live," ''New York Times'', September 28, 1997</ref><ref>Joel Garreau, The Next Generation; Biotechnology May Make Superhero Fantasy a Reality, ''Washington Post'', April 26, 2002.</ref>
Born in [[Bristol]], [[England]], More has a degree in [[Philosophy, Politics and Economics]] from Oxford University in [[St Anne's College, Oxford]] (1987).<ref>{{cite news|last=Regis|first=Ed|title=Meet the Extropians|url=https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/2.10/extropians_pr.html|newspaper=Wired}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Hughes|first=James|title=The Politics of Transhumanism|url=http://www.changesurfer.com/Acad/TranshumPolitics.htm}}</ref> His 1995 [[University of Southern California]] doctoral dissertation ''The Diachronic Self: Identity, Continuity, and Transformation'' examined several issues that concern transhumanists, including the nature of death, and what it is about each individual that continues despite great change over time.<ref>{{cite web|last=More |first=Max |title=The Diachronic Self: Identity, Continuity, Transformation |url=http://www.maxmore.com/disscont.htm |publisher=A. Bell & Howell |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040610182354/http://www.maxmore.com/disscont.htm |archivedate=2004-06-10 |df= }}</ref>
Founder of the [[Extropy Institute]], Max More has written many articles espousing the philosophy of [[transhumanism]] and the transhumanist philosophy of [[extropianism]],<ref>{{cite web|last=More|first=Max|title=The Philosophy of Transhumanism|url=http://media.johnwiley.com.au/product_data/excerpt/10/11183343/1118334310-109.pdf|publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Oxford|accessdate=16 May 2013}}</ref> most importantly his Principles of Extropy.<ref>{{cite web|last=More|first=Max|title=Principles of Extropy|url=http://www.extropy.org/principles.htm|work=Extropy Institute|accessdate=16 May 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131015142449/http://extropy.org/principles.htm|archivedate=15 October 2013|df=}}</ref><ref>Resources for Germline Technology, ''Washington Post'', February 9, 2003.</ref> In a 1990 essay "Transhumanism: Toward a Futurist Philosophy",<ref>{{cite web|last=More |first=Max |title=Transhumanism: Towards a Futurist Philosophy |url=http://www.maxmore.com/transhum.htm |accessdate=16 May 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051029125153/http://www.maxmore.com/transhum.htm |archivedate=29 October 2005 |df= }}</ref> he introduced the term "transhumanism" in its modern sense.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bostrom|first=Nick|title=A history of transhumanist thought|journal=Journal of Evolution and Technology|date=April 2005|volume=14|issue=1|pages=1–25|url=http://www.jetpress.org/volume14/bostrom.pdf}}</ref>
More is also noted for his writings about the impact of new and emerging technologies on businesses and other organizations. His "[[proactionary principle]]" is intended as a balanced guide to the risks and benefits of technological innovation.<ref>{{cite journal|last=More|first=Max|author2=N. Vita-More|title=The Proactionary Principle|journal=The Transhumanist Reader: Classical and Contemporary Essays on the Science, Technology, and Philosophy of the Human Future|date=11 March 2003|doi=10.1002/9781118555927.ch26|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/9781118555927.ch26/summary|accessdate=16 May 2013}}</ref>
At the start of 2011, Max More became president and CEO of the [[Alcor Life Extension Foundation]], an organization he joined in 1986.<ref>{{cite web|title=Alcor Life Extension Foundation Names Max More, PhD, as Chief Executive Officer|url=http://www.alcor.org/blog/?p=1473|work=Alcor News|accessdate=16 May 2013}}</ref>
==See also== * [[FM-2030]] * [[Futures studies]] * [[Humanity+]] * [[Natasha Vita-More]]

revision.comment: A metameme has absolutely nothing to do with a theory of eveolution.
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=July 2008}} {{Editorial|date=April 2011}}
In the field of [[memetics]], a '''metameme''' (or '''meta-meme''') is defined as a [[meme]] about a meme. A [[metaphor]] or the idea of [[memetic engineering]] are, thus, metamemes. The concept of memes has been referred to as "The Metameme".<ref>Glenn Grant. [http://deoxy.org/memelex.htm A Memetic Lexicon]</ref> Some other metamemes of interest include the [[meme tolerance]] and [[memeplex]]es.
Initial definitions of meta memes and the lingo surrounding the phenomenon have seen a recent overhaul, as a new perspective is beginning to emerge due to heightened interest from researchers and fortune 500 companies alike. Theories posited suggest that a meta meme is a meme about a meme. This process not only has brought about an entirely fresh way to view memes.
==Measuring social evolution== Metamemes may be used to measure the evolution of a given society. It has been proposed that the degree of [[consciousness]] one society has about the very [[meme]]s that form it is correlated with how evolved that society is. The difficulties associated with measuring the "metamemetic content" of a given society, however, render that proposition impractical.
This can be viewed (to some extent) as a memetic approach to the American sociologist [[Gerhard Lenski]]'s view that the more information a given society has, the more advanced it is.{{cn|date=May 2011}}
==See also== *[[Meme]] *[[Memetics]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://metameme.org/definition.html Definition] - MetaMeme.org
[[Category:Memetics|*]] [[Category:Philosophy of mind]]

A '''mode of toxic action''' is a common set of [[physiological]] and [[behavioral]] signs that characterize a type of adverse biological response.<ref name="rand">{{cite book | author = Rand G | title = Fundamentals of Aquatic Toxicology: Effects, Environmental Fate, and Risk Assessment | year = 1995 | publisher = CRC Press | location =Boca Raton, FL | isbn = 1-56032-091-5 }}</ref> A [[mode of action]] should not be confused with [[mechanism of action]], which refer to the [[biochemical]] processes underlying a given mode of action.<ref name="escher02">{{cite journal |vauthors=Escher BI, Hermens JL | title = Modes of action in ecotoxicology: their role in body burdens, species sensitivity, QSARs, and mixture effects | journal = Environ. Sci. Technol. | volume = 36 | issue = 20 | pages = 4201–17 |date=October 2002 | pmid = 12387389 | doi = 10.1021/es015848h}}</ref> Modes of toxic action are important, widely used tools in [[ecotoxicology]] and [[aquatic toxicology]] because they classify [[toxicant]]s or [[pollution|pollutants]] according to their type of toxic action. There are two major types of modes of toxic action: non-specific acting toxicants and specific acting toxicants. Non-specific acting toxicants are those that produce [[narcotic|narcosis]], while specific acting toxicants are those that are non-narcotic and that produce a specific action at a specific target site.
== Types ==
=== Non-specific ===
[[Wikipedia talk:Articles for creation/Fish Acute Toxicity Syndromes (FATS)|Non-specific acting modes of toxic action]] result in [[narcotic|narcosis]]; therefore, narcosis is a mode of toxic action. Narcosis is defined as a generalized depression in [[biological activity]] due to the presence of [[toxicant]] [[molecules]] in the organism.<ref name="rand" /> The target site and mechanism of toxic action through which narcosis affects organisms are still unclear, but there are [[hypothesis|hypotheses]] that support that it occurs through alterations in the [[cell membranes]] at specific sites of the membranes, such as the [[lipid bilayer|lipid layers]] or the [[proteins]] bound to the membranes. Even though continuous exposure to a [[narcotic]] toxicant can produce [[death]], if the exposure to the toxicant is stopped, narcosis can be reversible.
=== Specific ===
[[Toxicant]]s that at low [[concentrations]] modify or inhibit some biological process by binding at a specific site or [[molecule]] have a specific acting mode of toxic action.<ref name="rand" /> However, at high enough concentrations, toxicants with specific acting modes of toxic actions can produce [[narcotic|narcosis]] that may or may not be reversible. Nevertheless, the specific action of the toxicant is always shown first because it requires lower concentrations.
There are several specific acting modes of toxic action: *'''''[[Wikipedia talk:Articles for creation/Fish Acute Toxicity Syndromes (FATS)|Uncouplers of oxidative phosphorylation]]'''''. Involves toxicants that uncouple the two processes that occur in [[oxidative phosphorylation]]: [[electron transfer]] and [[adenosine triphosphate]] (ATP) production. * '''''Acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitors'''''. [[Acetylcholinesterase|AChE]] is an [[enzyme]] associated with [[nerve]] [[synapses]] that it’s designed to regulate nerve impulses by breaking down the [[neurotransmitter]] [[Acetylcholine]] (ACh). When toxicants bind to AChE, they inhibit the breakdown of ACh. This results in continued nerve impulses across the synapses, which eventually cause nerve system damage. Examples of AChE inhibitors are [[organophosphates]] and [[carbamates]], which are components found in [[pesticides]] (see [[Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors]]). * '''''Irritants'''''. These are chemicals that cause an [[inflammation|inflammatory]] effect on living tissue by chemical action at the site of contact. The resulting effect of [[Irritation|irritants]] is an increase in the [[volume]] of cells due to a change in size ([[hypertrophy]]) or an increase in the number of cells ([[hyperplasia]]). Examples of irritants are [[benzaldehyde]], [[acrolein]], [[zinc sulphate]] and [[chlorine]]. * '''''Central nervous system (CNS) seizure agents'''''. [[Central nervous system|CNS]] seizure agents inhibit [[cellular signaling]] by acting as [[receptor antagonists]]. They result in the inhibition of biological responses. Examples of CNS seizure agents are [[organochlorine]] [[pesticides]]. * '''''Respiratory blockers'''''. These are toxicants that affect [[Respiration (physiology)|respiration]] by interfering with the [[electron transport chain]] in the [[mitochondria]]. Examples of respiratory blockers are [[rotenone]] and [[cyanide]].
== Determination ==
The pioneer work of identifying the major categories of modes of toxic action (see description above) was conducted by investigators from the [[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) at the Duluth Laboratory using fish,<ref name="rand" /><ref name="mccarty93">{{cite journal|vauthors=McCarty LS, McCarty D | title = Enhancing ecotoxicological modeling and assessment: body residues and modes of toxic action|journal=Environmental Science & Technology | year = 1993 | volume = 27 | issue = 9 | pages = 1719–1728 | doi=10.1021/es00046a001}}</ref><ref name="escher10">{{cite journal |vauthors=Escher BI, Ashauer R, Dyer S, Hermens JL, Lee JH, Leslie HA, Mayer P, Meador JP, Warne MS | title = Crucial role of mechanisms and modes of toxic action for understanding tissue residue toxicity and internal effect concentrations of organic chemicals | journal = Integr Environ Assess Manag | volume = 7 | issue = 1 | pages = 28–49 |date=January 2011 | pmid = 21184568 | doi = 10.1002/ieam.100 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=McKim JM, Schmieder PK, Carlson RW, Hunt EP | title = Use of respiratory-cardiovascular responses of rainbow trout (Salmo gairdneri) in identifying acute toxicity syndromes in fish: Part 1. Pentachlorophenol, 2,4-dinitrophenol, tricaine methanesulfonate and 1-octanol | journal = Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry | year = 1987 | volume = 6 | pages = 295–312 | doi=10.1002/etc.5620060407}}</ref> reason why they named the categories as ''[[Wikipedia talk:Articles for creation/Fish Acute Toxicity Syndromes (FATS)|Fish Acute Toxicity Syndromes]]'' (FATS). They proposed the FATS by assessing the [[behavioral]] and [[physiological]] responses of the fish when subjected to [[toxicity test]]s, such as [[locomotive]] activities, body [[color]], [[ventilation (physiology)|ventilation]] patterns, [[cough]] [[rate function|rate]], [[heart rate]], and others.<ref name="escher02" />
It has been proposed that modes of toxic action could be estimated by developing a data set of critical body residues (CBR).<ref name="mccarty93" /> The CBR is the whole-body [[concentration]] of a chemical that is associated with a given adverse biological response<ref name="rand" /> and it is estimated using a [[partition coefficient]] and a [[bioconcentration]] factor. The whole-body residues are reasonable first [[approximations]] of the amount of chemical present at the toxic action site(s).<ref name="mccarty93" /> Because different modes of toxic action generally appear to be associated with different ranges of body residues,<ref name="mccarty93" /> modes of toxic action can then be separated into categories. However, it is unlikely that every chemical has the same mode of toxic action in every organism, so this [[Heart rate variability|variability]] should be considered.<ref name="mccarty93" /> The effects of [[mixture]] toxicity should be considered as well, even though mixture toxicity it's generally [[additive map|additive]],<ref name="mccarty93" /> chemicals with more than one mode of toxic action may contribute to toxicity.<ref name="escher10" />
[[Scientific modeling|Modeling]] has become a common used tool to predict modes of toxic action in the last decade. The [[mathematical model|models]] are based in [[Quantitative Structure-Activity Relationship]]s (QSARs), which are [[mathematical models]] that relate the [[biological activity]] of molecules to their [[chemical structure]]s and corresponding chemical and [[Physical chemistry|physicochemical]] properties.<ref name="rand" /> QSARs can then predict modes of toxic action of unknown compounds by comparing its characteristic toxicity profile and chemical structure to reference compounds with known toxicity profiles and chemical structures.<ref name="escher02" /> Russom and colleagues<ref name="russom">{{cite journal |vauthors=Russom CL, Bradbury SP, Broderius SJ, Hammermeister DE, Drummond RA | title = Predicting modes of toxic action from chemical structure: acute toxicity in the fathead minnow (Pimephales promelas) | journal = Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry | year = 1997 | volume = 16 | issue = 5 | pages = 948–967 | doi=10.1002/etc.5620160514}}</ref> were one of the first group of researchers being able to classify modes of toxic action with the use of QSARs; they classified 600 chemicals as narcotics. Even though QSARs are a useful tool for predicting modes of toxic action, chemicals having multiple modes of toxic action can obscure QSAR analyses. Therefore, these models are continuously being developed.
== Applications ==
=== Environmental risk assessment ===
The objective of environmental [[risk assessment]] is to protect the environment from adverse effects.<ref name="escher02" /> Researchers are further developing QSAR models with the ultimate goal providing a clear insight about a mode of toxic action, but also about what the actual target site is, the concentration of the chemical at this target site, and the interaction occurring at the target site,<ref name="escher02" /> as well as to predict the modes of toxic action in [[mixtures]]. Information on the mode of toxic action is crucial not only in understanding joint toxic effects and potential interactions between chemicals in mixtures, but also for developing assays for the evaluation of complex mixtures in the field.
=== Regulation ===
The combination of [[behavioral]] and [[physiological]] responses, CBR estimates, and chemical fate and [[bioaccumulation]] QSAR models can be a powerful regulatory tool<ref name="mccarty93" /> to address [[pollution]] and toxicity in areas where [[effluents]] are discharged.

{{for|the bird species with the common name mourner|Mourner (bird)}}
[[Image:Tumulo de D. Pedro I 57a.jpg|thumb|Mourning angels at the tomb of [[Pedro I of Portugal]] (died 1367), [[Alcobaça Monastery]] Mourning figures or "weepers" (French ''pleurants'') have been conventional elements of [[tomb]] architecture since the [[Gothic art|Gothic period]].]]
A '''mourner''' is someone who is attending a [[funeral]] or who is otherwise recognized as in a period of [[grief]] and [[mourning]] prescribed either by religious law or by popular custom.<ref>[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/mourner ''Mourner'' definition] at [[Merriam-Webster]]</ref> Many cultures expect mourners to curtail certain activities, usually those considered frivolous or that are accompanied by expressions of joy.
==History== Historically, some cultures have employed [[Professional mourning|professional mourners]] to make a public showing of grief to honor the deceased (particularly those in the [[Near East]]).<ref>Footnote 1 in Sabar, Y. (1976). "Lel-Huza: Story and History in a Cycle of Lamentations for the Ninth of Ab in the Jewish Neo-Aramaic Dialect of Zakho, Iraqi Kurdistan." ''Journal of Semitic Studies'' (21) 138-162.</ref>
==Business== Traced back to the year of 1877, it has been recorded that there is a business entailed with hiring or renting mourners for a funeral. It is said that a funeral with an abundance of mourners makes the deceased appear to have lived a well life. This leads people into renting mourners to show up at their funeral. The mourners are actors who are paid by the hour to mourn in the crowd. Before the funeral, the actors are informed about the deceased and the life that they lived. They are told about the life of the deceased so that they can casually talk to the crowd about as if they really knew them. It is even tradition in the African countries, Middle Eastern countries, and China to hire mourners.<ref name=TheHuffingtonPost>{{cite news|title='Rent A Mourner' Helps You Look More Popular At Your Funeral|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/03/27/rent-a-mourner_n_2964280.html|publisher=The Huffington Post|accessdate=1 November 2013|first=Catherine|last=New|date=27 March 2013}}</ref> It is even recorded that in China mourners are hired to belly dance and put on a theatrical spectacle at the funeral.<ref name=NPR>{{cite web|last=Lim|first=Louisa|title=Belly Dancing For The Dead: A Day With China's Top Mourner|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/06/26/195565696/belly-dancing-for-the-dead-a-day-with-chinas-top-mourner|publisher=NPR|accessdate=1 November 2013}}</ref><ref name=TIMEcnnNews>{{cite news|title=TIME News Feed|url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2013/04/04/want-to-look-more-popular-rent-a-mourner-will-send-people-to-your-funeral/|publisher=CNN News|accessdate=1 November 2013|date=4 April 2013}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Céline Figard | image = Celine Figard BBC photograph.png | image_upright = 0.9 | alt = A Caucasian female, probably in her late teens, with light brown hair and brown eyes wearing a white sleeveless shirt looking at the camera and smiling. Visible in the background are a red-and-white patio, a lawn and a white-painted building with an attached black drainpipe. | caption = Undated photograph of Figard | native_name = Céline Figard | native_name_lang = fr | pronunciation = {{IPA-fr|selin fiɡaʁ}} | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name above --> | birth_date = {{Birth date|1976|05|23|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Besançon]], France | disappeared_date = {{disappeared date|1995|12|19|df=yes}} | disappeared_place = [[Chieveley|Chieveley, Berkshire]], United Kingdom | death_date = {{disappeared date and age|1995|12|19|1976|5|23|df=yes}} | death_place = United Kingdom | death_cause = Homicide by strangulation and bludgeoning | body_discovered = [[Hawford|Hawford, Worcestershire]], United Kingdom<ref>{{cite news |first=Matthew |last=Brace |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/fears-grow-for-celine-after-body-is-found-1527720.html |title=Fears grow for Celine after body is found |publisher=Independent Print Limited |newspaper=The Independent |date=30 December 1995 |accessdate=9 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160805051256/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/fears-grow-for-celine-after-body-is-found-1527720.html |archivedate=5 August 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> | resting_place = [[Scey-sur-Saône-et-Saint-Albin|Scey-sur-Saône-et-Saint-Albin, Haute-Saône]], France | occupation = Accountancy student }} '''Céline Figard''' ({{IPA-fr|selin fiɡaʁ}}; 23 May 1976<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:QVZD-W7QZ|title=Person Details for Celine Figard, "England and Wales Death Registration Index 1837–2007"|last=|first=|date=4 September 2014|website=FamilySearch.org|publisher=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160813152412/https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:QVZD-W7QZ|archive-date=13 August 2016|dead-url=no|accessdate=13 August 2016}}</ref> – 19 December 1995) was a French woman who went missing and was murdered during a visit to the United Kingdom in December 1995. She accepted a lift from a lorry driver at the [[Chieveley services]] on the [[M4 motorway|M4]] in [[Chieveley]], [[Berkshire]], on 19 December, but never arrived at her destination. Following an appeal for information on her whereabouts and police enquiries, her body was discovered on 29 December, at a lay-by on the [[A449 road|A449]] in [[Hawford]], [[Worcestershire]]. A [[Autopsy|post-mortem examination]] determined she had been strangled and bludgeoned to death.
The case received extensive news coverage in the UK around the Christmas and New Year period, amid fears that it could be linked to a series of killings around the [[English Midlands]], which police called the work of a "Midlands Ripper". The murder investigation included the UK's first national [[DNA profiling|DNA screening]] programme in the hunt for a murder suspect, covering over 5,000 people.
Stuart William Morgan, a 36-year-old lorry driver from [[Poole]], [[Dorset]], was arrested in February 1996 after a colleague recognised his image from a [[photofit]]. Morgan was later charged with Figard's murder, and convicted in October. Detectives concluded that after raping, strangling and bludgeoning her, he carried her body in his vehicle for ten days over the Christmas period before dumping it. Morgan was given a [[life sentence]], with a recommendation to serve at least twenty years. An appeal in February 1998 was rejected by the [[Court of Appeal of England and Wales|Court of Appeal]], and in 2009 the [[High Court of England and Wales|High Court]] turned down his application for a review of the length of his sentence. He became eligible for [[parole]] in February 2016, and has continued to maintain his innocence.
Figard was buried in the French village of [[Scey-sur-Saône-et-Saint-Albin]], [[Haute-Saône]], at a service attended by her family, friends and politicians in January 1996. In the UK, she is remembered in a memorial garden established at a church in the Worcestershire village of [[Ombersley]], close to where her body was discovered.
==Background and disappearance== Céline Figard was born on 23 May 1976 in [[Besançon]], France, to Martine and Bernard Figard.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.astrologie-gratuite.org|title=Données de naissances|last=|first=|date=|website=astrologie-gratuite.org|publisher=|language=French|access-date=23 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160907041004/http://www.astrologie-gratuite.org/|archivedate=7 September 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> She had two brothers, Stephane and Nicolas, and a sister, Karine.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.letelegramme.fr/ar/viewarticle1024.php?aaaammjj=19961017&article=19961017-1243484&type=ar|title=Unanimité contre le meurtrier de Céline|accessdate=9 July 2016|newspaper=Le Télégramme|date=17 October 1996|language=French|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180117203807/http://www.letelegramme.fr/ar/viewarticle1024.php?aaaammjj=19961017&article=19961017-1243484&type=ar|archivedate=17 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> At the time of her death, she was studying accountancy at the Lycée le Grand Chênois in [[Montbéliard]]. She developed a fondness for the United Kingdom following a 1990 visit and travelled there repeatedly.<ref name=DailyMail-1996-10-17/><ref name="WorcesterNews-2000-12-29">{{cite news|url=http://www.worcesternews.co.uk/news/7777206._Why_did_he_kill_our_daughter__/|title=Why did he kill our daughter?|date=29 December 2000|publisher=Newsquest Media Group|newspaper=Worcester News|accessdate=25 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160825195448/http://www.worcesternews.co.uk/news/7777206._Why_did_he_kill_our_daughter__/|archivedate=25 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.worcesternews.co.uk/news/7754218.English_learning_curve_for_Christelle/|title=English learning curve for Christelle|date=4 July 2001|publisher=Newsquest Media Group|newspaper=Worcester News|accessdate=25 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160825185539/http://www.worcesternews.co.uk/news/7754218.English_learning_curve_for_Christelle/|archivedate=25 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
[[File:Lorry park at Chieveley services - geograph.org.uk - 927969.jpg|thumb|left|The lorry park of Chieveley Services in 2008. Figard was last seen alive here on the afternoon of 19 December 1995.]] Figard spent the summer of 1995 working at a hotel in [[Fordingbridge]], [[Hampshire]], where her cousin Jean-Marc was head waiter, using the opportunity to improve her English.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.itnsource.com/shotlist//RTV/1995/12/27/605261820/?s=|title=UK: Father of missing French student Celine Figard, appeals to public for help in finding his daughter.|website=www.itnsource.com|accessdate=9 July 2016|publisher=ITN source}}</ref> She returned to the UK in December to spend another two weeks with Jean-Marc.<ref name=WorcesterNews-2000-12-29/> After leaving on Monday, 18 December, she travelled with a family friend employed by a local haulage firm to the French coast, as arranged by her parents, and crossed the [[English Channel]] the following day,<ref name=Independent-1996-10-03/><ref name=Openshaw/> arriving in [[Ashford, Kent|Ashford]], [[Kent]]. She intended to travel to [[Fordingbridge]] by train; her escort found another French lorry driver, Roger Bouvier, who was willing to take her to [[Chieveley services|Chieveley Services]] near [[Newbury, Berkshire|Newbury]], [[Berkshire]].<ref name=Independent-1996-10-03/><ref name=Openshaw/><ref name=BirminghamPost-1998-02-06/>
When they arrived, Figard tried to phone Jean-Marc to ask him to pick her up, but misdialed.<ref name=DailyMail-1996-10-03>{{cite news|url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-110886301.html|title= Killer kept Celine's body behind his driver's seat for ten days|publisher= Associated Newspapers Ltd|newspaper= Daily Mail|format= subscription required|date= 3 October 1996|accessdate= 23 August 2012|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20130125054941/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-110886301.html|archivedate= 25 January 2013|df= dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{cite news|url= http://www.thefreelibrary.com/EYES+OF+PURE+EVIL%3B+I+saw+killer+with+Celine.-a061306658|title= Eyes of pure evil: I saw killer with Celine|first= Howard|last= Souness|publisher= Mirror Group Newspapers|newspaper= The Mirror|date= 17 October 1996|accessdate= 25 August 2012}}</ref> She was offered a lift to [[Salisbury]] by the driver of a white [[Mercedes-Benz|Mercedes]] lorry.<ref name=":0" /> Bouvier had reservations about the driver,<ref name="Independent-1996-10-17" /> but let her go with him nonetheless. Figard left the service station with the driver at around 4:30 pm.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.liberation.fr/planete/1996/10/03/celine-figard-la-mortelle-randonnee-le-proces-de-stuart-morgan-l-assassin-presume-s-est-ouvert-en-an_185096|title=Céline Figard: la mortelle randonnée. Le procès de Stuart Morgan, l'assassin présumé, s'est ouvert en Angleterre.|last=Leauthier|first=Alain|date=3 October 1996|work=Libération|language=fr|accessdate=13 August 2016|via=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160610031807/http://www.liberation.fr/planete/1996/10/03/celine-figard-la-mortelle-randonnee-le-proces-de-stuart-morgan-l-assassin-presume-s-est-ouvert-en-an_185096|archivedate=10 June 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> She never arrived at her destination, and was reported missing.
Police appealed for information about her disappearance, and issued a [[photofit]] of the lorry driver, but he was not identified. By 25 December, investigators were working on the theory that he had abducted her.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/police-fear-lorry-driver-abducted-french-student-1527320.html|title= Police fear lorry driver abducted French student|publisher= Independent Print Ltd|newspaper= The Independent|date= 26 December 1996|accessdate= 25 August 2012|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140714124821/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/police-fear-lorry-driver-abducted-french-student-1527320.html|archivedate= 14 July 2014|df= dmy-all}}</ref> The following day, investigators were working on the assumption she had been murdered.<ref name=Independent-1995-12-27/> Figard's father travelled to the UK to help detectives in their search for her and to appeal to the public for information as to her whereabouts.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.itnsource.com/shotlist//RTV/1995/12/27/605261820/?s=* |title=Father of missing French student Celine Figard appeals to public for help in finding his daughter|publisher=ITN |work= ITN News|date=27 December 1995 |accessdate=22 August 2012}}</ref>
==Discovery of body and autopsy== On the morning of Friday, 29 December, the naked body of a young woman was found dumped at a lay-by on the [[A449 road|A449]] near the [[Worcestershire]] village of [[Hawford]] by a motorist who had stopped to change a windscreen wiper.<ref name=Independent-1995-12-31/> Police sought to establish her identity, but were sure it was not that of Louise Smith, an 18-year-old clerical assistant who had vanished early on Christmas Day after attending a nightclub at [[Yate]], [[Gloucestershire]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Matthew |last=Brace |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/fears-grow-for-celine-after-body-is-found-1527720.html |title=Fears grow for Celine after body is found |publisher=Independent Print Ltd |newspaper=The Independent |date=30 December 1995 |accessdate=22 August 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140125041704/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/fears-grow-for-celine-after-body-is-found-1527720.html |archivedate=25 January 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Smith's body was discovered in February 1996 in [[Chipping Sodbury, South Gloucestershire|Chipping Sodbury]], [[South Gloucestershire]].<ref>{{cite news|first=|last=|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/54914.stm|title=Former student jailed for Christmas Day murder|publisher=BBC News|newspaper=|date=9 February 1998|accessdate=18 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170813020625/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/54914.stm|archivedate=13 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The body was positively identified as that of Figard the following day. The [[post mortem]] determined she had been strangled and bludgeoned with a heavy implement, but did not establish which was fatal. The autopsy revealed "no obvious signs" of sexual assault,<ref name=Independent-1995-12-31/> but it was determined that sexual intercourse had taken place shortly before her death, and detectives believed it had occurred against her will.<ref name=Independent-1996-01-13>{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Mowbray |first2=Jason |last2=Bennetto |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/dna-test-for-1200-lorry-drivers-1323711.html |title=DNA test for 1,200 lorry drivers |publisher=Independent Print Ltd |newspaper=The Independent |date=13 January 1996 |accessdate=22 August 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714154419/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/dna-test-for-1200-lorry-drivers-1323711.html |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Police said that the body had been lying where it was found for about twenty-four hours and were working on the theory that she had been held captive before being killed. [[Detective Chief Superintendent]] Roger Hoddinott of [[Hampshire Police]] said at the time of discovery, Figard had been dead for at least four to five days, but did not announce a time of death.<ref name="Independent-1995-12-31">{{cite news |first=Will |last=Bennett |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/killer-hid-celine-for-days-1527893.html |title=Killer hid Celine 'for days' |publisher=Independent Print Ltd |newspaper=The Independent |date=31 December 1995 |accessdate=22 August 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714233252/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/killer-hid-celine-for-days-1527893.html |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Investigation== The investigation was led by DCS John McCammont of [[West Mercia Police]],<ref name=Independent-1996-01-05/> and involved more than 100 detectives from three police forces.<ref name=WorcesterNews-2000-12-29/><ref name=Independent-1995-12-27>{{cite news|url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/missing-girls-father-helps-in-murder-hunt-1527423.html|title= Missing girl's father helps in murder hunt|first= Matthew|last= Brace|newspaper= The Independent|publisher= Independent Print Ltd|date= 27 December 1995|accessdate= 26 August 2012|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140714222700/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/missing-girls-father-helps-in-murder-hunt-1527423.html|archivedate= 14 July 2014|df= dmy-all}}</ref> Officers examined similar unsolved murders amid concerns that they could all be the work of the same individual.<ref name=DailyMail-1996-01-01>{{cite news|url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-111436649.html|title= Celine might have been serial killer's tenth victim|publisher= Associated Newspapers|newspaper= Daily Mail|subscription= yes|date= 1 January 1996|accessdate= 26 August 2012|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20130126010204/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-111436649.html|archivedate= 26 January 2013|df= dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Ian |last=MacKinnon |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/police-swap-evidence-in-hunt-for-celines-killer-po-1322015.html |title=Police swap evidence in hunt for Celine's killer |publisher=Independent Print Ltd |newspaper=The Independent |date=2 January 1996 |accessdate=27 August 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714121451/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/police-swap-evidence-in-hunt-for-celines-killer-po-1322015.html |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Of particular interest were the recent murders of Tracey Turner and Samo Paull, whose bodies were also found on motorways after they had been strangled.<ref name=DailyMail-1996-01-01/> McCammont ruled out a link at a press conference on 4 January: "I would stress that at this stage there is no firm evidence whatsoever to link Céline's murder with any other investigations."<ref name=Independent-1996-01-05/> He appealed for information concerning a bottle of [[Pascal Chretien]] champagne, a gift given to Figard before she came to England: "This particular type of champagne is not exported to anywhere in the world outside France and is not sold in this country. It is a 1993 vintage and only 60,000 bottles have been produced."<ref name=Independent-1996-01-05>{{cite news |first=Will |last=Bennett |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/serial-killer-link-to-celine-ruled-out-1322421.html |title=Serial killer link to Celine ruled out |publisher=Independent Print Ltd |newspaper=The Independent |date=5 January 1996 |accessdate=22 August 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714205000/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/serial-killer-link-to-celine-ruled-out-1322421.html |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
On 12 January 1996, investigators announced that they would perform [[DNA testing]] on the drivers of all vehicles similar to the Mercedes. This was the first time the method was used nationally to identify a murder suspect.<ref name=Independent-1996-01-13/><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.parliament.uk/briefing-papers/RP96-44.pdf|title= DNA Fingerprinting: Research Paper 96/44|publisher= Parliament.uk|page= 27|date= 27 March 1996|accessdate= 15 September 2012}}</ref> Detectives traced more than 1,000 vehicles and tested 5,000 drivers.<ref name=WorcesterNews-2000-12-29/> On 19 February, West Mercia Police confirmed that a man had been arrested and was helping them with their inquiries.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-110855456.html|title= Man held in search for Celine sex killer|format= subscription required|publisher= Associated Newspapers Ltd|newspaper= Daily Mail|date= 20 February 1996|accessdate= 22 August 2012|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20130125073738/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-110855456.html|archivedate= 25 January 2013|df= dmy-all}}</ref> The following day, authorities announced that the suspect was English and had been arrested in [[Poole]], [[Dorset]] in a joint operation between West Mercia and [[Dorset Police]].<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/celine-joint-swoop-1320051.html|title= Celine joint swoop|publisher= Independent Print Ltd|newspaper= The Independent|date= 21 February 1996|accessdate= 24 August 2012|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140715014228/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/celine-joint-swoop-1320051.html|archivedate= 15 July 2014|df= dmy-all}}</ref> He was subsequently identified as Stuart Morgan, a 36-year-old self-employed lorry driver, who on 21 February was remanded following an appearance at [[Redditch]] magistrates.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/celine-remand-1320236.html |title=Celine remand |publisher=Independent Print Ltd |newspaper=The Independent |date=22 February 1996 |accessdate=22 August 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714142300/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/celine-remand-1320236.html |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Stuart Morgan== {{Infobox criminal | name = Stuart Morgan | image = | image_upright = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Stuart William Morgan | birth_date = {{birth based on age as of date|56|2016|01|26}}<ref>{{cite news|last1=Al Rasheed|first1=Tarik|title=Lorry driver who murdered teenager can ask to be freed|url=http://www.worcesternews.co.uk/news/14231324.Lorry_driver_who_murdered_teenager_can_ask_to_be_freed/?ref=mr&lp=11|accessdate=14 August 2016|work=Worcester News|date=26 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160916092550/http://www.worcesternews.co.uk/news/14231324.Lorry_driver_who_murdered_teenager_can_ask_to_be_freed/?ref=mr&lp=11|archivedate=16 September 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> | birth_place = | residence = | nationality = English | occupation = Lorry driver | criminal_charge = Murder | conviction_penalty = Life imprisonment | conviction_status = In prison | conviction = Murder }} Stuart William Morgan is an English lorry driver and former heating engineer from Poole. One of five children of John and Julianne Morgan, he was raised in [[Royal Tunbridge Wells|Tunbridge Wells]], [[Kent]], where his father was employed as a council foreman and his mother – a refugee from the former [[East Germany]] – worked as a school cleaner. Morgan left school with three [[Certificate of Secondary Education|CSE]]s, and in 1974 served a custodial sentence in [[borstal]] following a conviction for burglary. After attending [[Croydon Polytechnic]] to train as a plumber and heating engineer, he established a plumbing business in the Tunbridge Wells area. He moved to Dorset following the failure of that business in 1983 and worked as a heating engineer for [[Bournemouth Borough Council]]. He became a lorry driver in 1991.<ref name=DailyMail-1996-10-17/><ref name=Openshaw>{{cite web|url= http://www.hmcourts-service.gov.uk/cms/144_14961.htm|archiveurl= http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20110218200720/http:/www.hmcourts-service.gov.uk/cms/144_14961.htm|dead-url= yes|archivedate= 18 February 2011|title= High Court setting of minimum terms for mandatory life sentences under the Criminal Justice Act 2003: Neutral Citation Number: [2009] EWHC 1629|publisher= HM Government of the United Kingdom|work= Her Majesty's Courts Service|date= 27 July 2009|accessdate= 29 August 2012|first= The Hon. Mr Justice|last= Openshaw}}</ref>
Morgan met his first wife in Kent in the early 1980s. They married in 1982, but he left her when she became pregnant with twins. He met another woman after moving to Dorset. She also became pregnant, giving birth to a son, and they married in 1994, after living together for several years. Morgan had a reputation as a womaniser, seducing customers while working as an engineer. He continued this activity after becoming a lorry driver. Following his conviction, his brother Ray Morgan said, "He has had so many affairs over the years I have lost count." He also had a violent temper. One friend, Dave Moemken, described him as being "on a short fuse".<ref name=DailyMail-1996-10-17/>
Morgan was driving from [[Leeds]] to [[Southampton Docks]] when he picked up Figard on 19 December 1995.<ref name=DailyMail-1996-10-17/> Detectives concluded that after raping and killing her, Morgan left her body in the bottom bunk of his cab for up to ten days while he continued to drive the lorry, driving and sleeping in it for at least some of that time,<ref name=DailyMail-1996-10-17/><ref name=Independent-1996-10-17/> before disposing of the body on 29 December.<ref name=Independent-1996-10-17>{{cite news |first=Clare |last=Garner |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/life-for-lorry-driver-who-ended-celines-journey-of-optimism-1358724.html |title=Life for lorry driver who ended Celine's journey of optimism |publisher=Independent Print Ltd |newspaper=The Independent |date=17 October 1996 |accessdate=22 August 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714160235/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/life-for-lorry-driver-who-ended-celines-journey-of-optimism-1358724.html |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> He was arrested in February 1996 after another lorry driver recognised him from a photofit. Morgan initially denied meeting her, but after he was picked out at an [[Police lineup|identity parade]], he claimed he and Figard had met and engaged in consensual sex.<ref name="DailyRecord-1996-10-17" />
==Trial== The trial began at [[Worcester Crown Court]] on 2 October 1996,<ref name="Independent-1996-10-03">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/driver-hid-celines-body-in-his-lorry-1355356.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714173629/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/driver-hid-celines-body-in-his-lorry-1355356.html|title=Driver `hid Celine's body in his lorry'|date=3 October 1996|archive-date=14 July 2014|publisher=Independent Print ltd|newspaper=The Independent|accessdate=25 June 2016}}</ref> before Mr Justice Latham and a jury.<ref name=Independent-1996-10-17/> Morgan's trial counsel was Nigel Jones [[Queen's Counsel|QC]],<ref name=DailyMail-1996-10-11/> and the case was prosecuted by David Farrer QC.<ref name=Independent-1996-10-03/> Morgan denied the charge.<ref name=Independent-1996-10-17/>
[[File:Crown Court on Foregate street - geograph.org.uk - 1164418.jpg|thumb|right|Morgan's trial was held at Worcester Crown Court in October 1996.]] The prosecution account was that Morgan raped and killed Figard on the afternoon or evening of 19 December 1995, then kept her body in his cab for ten days before disposing of it.<ref name=DailyMail-1996-10-03/> Farrer told the court that she had been strangled and battered around the head with a heavy object, and injuries to her face were "consistent with kicking and stamping". There was also evidence to suggest her hands had been taped together, with the prosecution of the opinion she had been "intimidated" into having sex.<ref name=DailyMail-1996-10-03/>
Evidence was presented by the prosecution to suggest that Morgan continued to use the vehicle while Figard's body lay in the cab, and that the lorry was parked outside his house over the Christmas period. Farrer said Morgan bought a spade, axe and hacksaw with the intention of dismembering the body, but changed his mind,<ref name=DailyMail-1996-10-03/> instead making an overnight delivery run to dispose of it.<ref name=Independent-1996-10-03/> After removing a fuse from his lorry's [[tachograph]] to conceal the journey, he drove to Worcestershire.<ref name=Independent-1996-10-03/> Discrepancies were subsequently found in his travel records for 29 December 1995 because he forgot to replace the fuse following the trip.<ref name=Independent-1996-10-03/> DNA tests on spots of blood found in the cab matched Figard, while a blood-soaked mattress was found in Morgan's garage.<ref name=DailyMail-1996-10-03/> Several items belonging to Figard, including photographs and a toilet bag, were recovered from his house.<ref name=Mirror-1996-10-04>{{cite news|url= http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Celine+photos+at+trucker's+home.-a061272545|title= Celine photos at trucker's home|first= Bill|last= Daniels|newspaper= The Mirror|publisher= Mirror Group Newspapers|date= 4 October 1996|accessdate= 23 August 2012}}</ref> Some of her clothing was found close to a warehouse he had visited the night the body was dumped.<ref name=DailyMail-1996-10-03/> Morgan gave two bottles of Pascal Chretien that Figard had brought to England as Christmas presents to two garage attendants who worked at a [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell]] station opposite his house.<ref name=DailyMail-1996-10-03/>
Morgan admitted giving Figard a lift on the afternoon of 19 December 1995.<ref name=DailyMail-1996-10-11>{{cite news|url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-111321364.html|title= Murder-charge lorry driver gives evidence|newspaper= Daily Mail|publisher= Associated Newspapers Ltd|subscription= yes|date= 11 October 1996|accessdate= 23 August 2012|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20130125155414/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-111321364.html|archivedate= 25 January 2013|df= dmy-all}}</ref> He claimed that the pair had consensual sex after chatting and flirting, developing a rapport and halting at a lay-by where he made her a cup of tea and asked her for what he described as a "Christmas kiss".<ref name=DailyMail-1996-10-11/> He said afterwards he drove her to [[Southampton]], where they exchanged contact details before he left her,<ref name=DailyMail-1996-10-11/> and that she was "smiling and happy".<ref name=Independent-1996-10-11>{{cite news|url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/celine-case-man-tells-of-kiss-1357750.html|title= Celine case man tells of kiss|publisher= Independent Print Ltd|newspaper= The Independent|date= 11 October 1996|accessdate= 24 August 2012|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140715015913/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/celine-case-man-tells-of-kiss-1357750.html|archivedate= 15 July 2014|df= dmy-all}}</ref> He did not come forward after police appealed for details of the driver who had given her a lift because he did not want his wife to learn of his infidelity.<ref name=Independent-1996-10-11/> He claimed her photographs and other belongings were in his possession because she had left them in his truck,<ref name=Mirror-1996-10-04/> and the mattress had become stained with blood because a man had lain on it after gashing his leg while the vehicle was on loan to another driver in 1994.<ref name=WorcesterNews-2000-12-29/>
On 16 October, a jury took three and a half hours to convict Morgan of Figard's murder, and he was sentenced to [[life imprisonment]] with a recommendation that the [[Home Secretary]] should decide his [[parole]] eligibility.<ref name=DailyMail-1996-10-17>{{cite news|url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-111320617.html|title= As lorry driver is sent down for life, police reveal there may be a stringof other victims|first= Luke|last= Harding|newspaper= Daily Mail|publisher= Associated Newspapers Ltd|subscription= yes|date= 17 October 1996|accessdate= 23 August 2012|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20130125043323/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-111320617.html|archivedate= 25 January 2013|df= dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=DailyRecord-1996-10-17/> Passing sentence, Mr Justice Latham said, "What you did to Céline has caused revulsion in the minds of all right-thinking people. You are a dangerous man and I will so report to the Home Secretary."<ref name=Independent-1996-10-17/><ref name=DailyRecord-1996-10-17>{{cite news|url= http://www.thefreelibrary.com/CELINE+BEAST+CAGED+FOR+LIFE%3B+Killer+faces+quiz+on+other+deaths.-a061252431|title= Celine beast caged for life|newspaper= Daily Record|publisher= Mirror Group Newspapers|date= 17 October 1996|accessdate= 24 August 2012}}</ref> Latham subsequently set a minimum term of twenty years, which was later endorsed by the [[Lord Chief Justice of England and Wales]], [[Thomas Bingham, Baron Bingham of Cornhill|Lord Bingham]], and on 4 November 1998, the Home Secretary informed Morgan of the length of the sentence he must serve.<ref name=Openshaw/>
==Appeals== Morgan [[appeal]]ed his conviction on the grounds that it was unfair due to the level of publicity the case had received. His application was rejected by the [[Court of Appeal of England and Wales]] on 5 February 1998 after the three sitting judges ruled there were insufficient grounds to justify an appeal.<ref name=BirminghamPost-1998-02-06>{{cite news|url= http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Celine+killer's+appeal+bid+is+turned+down.-a060790110|title= Celine killer's appeal bid is turned down|publisher= Mirror Group Newspapers|newspaper= The Birmingham Post|date= 6 February 1998|accessdate= 25 August 2012}}</ref>
In January 2009, Morgan appealed again under paragraph 3 of Schedule 22 of the [[Criminal Justice Act 2003]] to the [[High Court of England and Wales]] requesting a review of the minimum term recommendation. This too was rejected, in July of that year, with the presiding judge, [[Peter Openshaw|Mr Justice Openshaw]] recommending, "The sentence is – and remains – a sentence of imprisonment for life. The defendant may not even be considered for release until he has served at least 20 years (less the time served before sentence). That is not to say that he will then be released; indeed he will be detained unless and until the Parole Board is satisfied that he no longer presents a risk to the public. Even if the Parole Board decides then or at some time in the future to authorise his release, he will be upon licence which will extend for the rest of his life."<ref name=Openshaw/>
In January 2016, Morgan appealed against the [[Ministry of Justice (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Justice]] after it decided not to downgrade his prisoner status from that of a [[Prisoner security categories in the United Kingdom|Category A prisoner]], as well as challenging the [[Parole Board for England and Wales|Parole Board]] for refusing to allow him an oral hearing. A hearing at the High Court on 26 January was told that under the terms of his sentence, Morgan would be eligible for parole from February, but had continued to maintain his innocence throughout his time in prison, claiming to be in a "[[Catch-22 (logic)|Catch-22]]" situation where he could not qualify for release without admitting his guilt. Rejecting Morgan's case, Justice [[William Davis (judge)|William Davis]] suggested that Morgan had not "addressed his offending behaviour" and was "in effect in the same position as in December 1995, when he murdered his victim".<ref>{{cite news |first=Tarik |last=Al Rasheed |url=http://www.worcesternews.co.uk/news/14231324.Lorry_driver_who_murdered_teenager_can_ask_to_be_freed/ |title=Lorry driver who murdered teenager can ask to be freed |newspaper=Worcester News) |publisher=Newsquest |date=26 January 2016 |accessdate=24 May 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160803062805/http://www.worcesternews.co.uk/news/14231324.Lorry_driver_who_murdered_teenager_can_ask_to_be_freed/ |archivedate=3 August 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[File:Entrance to St Andrew's Church - geograph.org.uk - 1139028.jpg|thumb|150px|The entrance to St Andrew's Church in Ombersley, Worcestershire, where services are held in Figard's memory]]
==Aftermath and memorials== Figard's body was flown home to France on 17 January 1996, where her funeral was held on 20 January.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/celine-figards-body-flown-home-1324493.html|title= Celine Figard's body flown home|publisher= Independent Print Ltd|newspaper= The Independent|date= 18 January 1996|accessdate= 25 August 2012|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140714233139/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/celine-figards-body-flown-home-1324493.html|archivedate= 14 July 2014|df= dmy-all}}</ref> She was buried in [[Scey-sur-Saône-et-Saint-Albin]]. ''[[The Mail on Sunday]]'' reported that the ceremony was attended by 3,000 mourners, including family, friends and French politicians.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-111434521.html|title= Thousands pay tribute to Celine|publisher= Associated Newspapers Ltd|newspaper= The Mail on Sunday|subscription= yes|date= 21 January 1996|accessdate= 25 August 2012|via= HighBeam Research|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20130125121636/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-111434521.html|archivedate= 25 January 2013|df= dmy-all}}</ref>
A memorial garden dedicated to Figard was planted at St Andrew's Church in the village of [[Ombersley]], Worcestershire, close to where her body was found, and opened at a ceremony in June 1997.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/a-colourful-memorial-to-tragic-celine-1256230.html|title= A colourful memorial to tragic Celine|publisher= Independent Print Ltd|newspaper= The Independent|date= 16 June 1997|accessdate= 26 August 2012|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140715000621/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/a-colourful-memorial-to-tragic-celine-1256230.html|archivedate= 15 July 2014|df= dmy-all}}</ref> Local residents raised more than £1,000 to help with its construction.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-110824986.html|title= For our daughters|publisher= Associated Newspapers Ltd|newspaper= Daily Mail|first= Bill|last= Mouland|date= 17 July 1997|accessdate= 5 April 2013|subscription= yes|via= HighBeam Research|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20130629102856/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-110824986.html|archivedate= 29 June 2013|df= dmy-all}}</ref> The garden also remembers other victims of violent crime, including [[Murder of Joanna Parrish|Joanna Parrish]] and Caroline Dickinson, two English students who were murdered in France. On 29 December 2000, the fifth anniversary of the date Figard's body was recovered, the local newspaper, the ''[[Worcester News]]'' reported that an annual service of remembrance was held for her at the church during the autumn, attended by her parents. Flowers were also regularly placed at the lay-by at Hawford where she was found, and the location named ''Le Jardin de Céline'' (Céline's Garden) in her memory.<ref name=WorcesterNews-2000-12-29/><ref>{{Cite news|first=Jean|last=Pascal|url=http://archives.lesoir.be/les-parents-de-la-jeune-fille-ont-salue-la-police-brita_t-19961017-Z0CRKH.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100214062931/http://archives.lesoir.be/les-parents-de-la-jeune-fille-ont-salue-la-police-brita_t-19961017-Z0CRKH.html|title=Les parents de la jeune fille ont salut la police Britanni |work=Le Soir|publisher=Rossel & Cie. S.A.|date=17 October 1996|archivedate=14 February 2010|accessdate=9 July 2016|language=French}}</ref>
